viii ABSTRACT

ANDRADE , Lucas Santos . Adsorption of naphthenic acids from aqueous so- lution using activated carbon and acute toxicity evaluation with bacterium Vibrio fischeri . Rio de Janeiro, 202 2. Disserta√ß√£o (Mestrado em Engenharia de Processos Qu√≠micos e Bioqu√≠micos) - Escola de Qu√≠mica, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeir o, Rio de Janeiro, 202 2.

Naphthenic acids (NA) refer to the complex class of cycloaliphatic carboxylic ac- ids present in crude oil in different concentrations depending on the source. They are considered the most toxic component of the main effluent generated during oil exploration , called produced water (PW). In addition to its potential tox icity to the aquatic environment if dis charged incorrectly, the presence of NA causes several problems in the oil exploration and refining stages, such as corrosion, emulsions and incrustations in pipes and equipment. Methods of NA removal have been studied, including adsorption using activated carbon , to reduce the toxicity of PW and improve operational conditions. Given this scenario, t his work aims to evaluate the adsorption process as a treat ment of synthetic solutions containing cyclohexanecarboxylic acid (C HA) and cyclohexanebutyric acid (CHB), carrying out the study of the best conditions of pH and a commercial ac- tivated carbon concentration. Therefore, a kinetic study was carried out of the adsorption and adjustment to the pseudo -first order, pseudo -second order and intraparticle diffusion models of the best conditions . The study of isotherms was made, adjusting the results to the models of Langmuir, Freundlich and Temk in.

The toxic effects of these substances in pre and post -treatment samples were investigated using the marine bacterium Vibrio fischeri . The results demonstrated that the adsorption process achieved NA removal greater than 80% at pH = 4 and 5 g/L of activ ated carbon . The pseudo -second order (kinetic) and Freundlich (iso- thermal) models showed the best fit to the experimental data (R¬≤ > 0.9). The or- ganic substance CHA present ed slight toxicity in the studied concentration, while the CHB presented effective c oncentration causing adverse effect in 50% of test organisms within 30 minutes (EC50,30min) = 4.97%, considered very toxic. In terms of EC 20,30min , both organic substances had an inhibitory effect, being considered as toxic. After treatment, the EC 50,30min observed for the C HB was higher than 81.9%, indicating a reduction in the toxic character of the sample, being classified as slightly toxic. In addition, the treatment vi a adsorption with activated carbon achieved a reduction of 78% and 29% in the percentage of inhibition for C HB and CHA, respectively. Thus, the adsorption process with activated carbon proved to be promising in removing and reducing the CHA and CHB toxicit y.

Adsorption of naphthenic acids in aqueous solution using activated carbon and acute toxicity evaluation with bacterium Vibrio fischeri .
Lucas S. Andrade, Alyne M. Costa, Juacyara C. Campos

Abstract Naphthenic acids (NA) refer to the complex class of cycl oaliphatic carboxylic acids pre- sent in crude oil in different concentrations depending on the source. They are considered the most toxic component of the main effluent generated during oil exploration, called produced water (PW). In addition to its potenti al toxicity to the aquatic environment if discharged incorrectly, the presence of NA causes several problems in the oil exploration and refining stages, such as corrosion, emulsions and incrustations in pipes and equip- ment. Methods of NA removal have been studied, including adsorption using activated carbon, to reduce the toxicity of PW and improve operational conditions. Given this sce- nario, this work aims to evaluate the adsorption process as a treatment of synthetic solu- tions containing cyclohexanecarbox ylic acid (CHA) and cyclohexanebutyric acid (CHB), carrying out the study of the best conditions of pH and a commercial activated carbon concentration. Therefore, a kinetic study was carried out of the adsorption and adjustment to the pseudo -first order, p seudo -second order and intraparticle diffusion models of the best conditions. The study of isotherms was made, adjusting the results to the models of Langmuir, Freundlich and Temkin. The toxic effects of these substances in pre and post - treatment samples w ere investigated using the marine bacterium Vibrio fischeri . The re- sults demonstrated that the adsorption process achieved NA removal greater than 80% at pH = 4 and 5 g/L of activated carbon. The pseudo -second order (kinetic) and Freundlich (isothermal) models showed the best fit to the experimental data (R¬≤ > 0.9). The organic substance CHA presented slight toxicity in the studied concentration, while the CHB pre- sented effective concentration causing adverse effect in 50% of test organisms w ithin 30 minutes (EC 50,30min ) = 4.97%, considered very toxic. In terms of EC 20,30min , both organic substances had an inhibitory effect, being considered as toxic. After treatment, the EC 50,30min observed for the CHB was higher than 81.9%, indicating a redu ction in the toxic character of the sample, being classified as slightly toxic. In addition, the treatment via adsorption with activated carbon achieved a reduction of 78% and 29% in the per- centage of inhibition for CHB and CHA, respectively. Thus, the ads orption process with activated carbon proved to be promising in removing and reducing the CHA and CHB toxicity.
Keywords: Naphtenic acids, ecotoxicity, adsorption, Vibrio fischeri , activated carbon.
1. Introduction

World oil production tends to grow in the coming years, despite being a fossil fuel, oil represented more than 50% of the energy source consumed in the world, accord- ing to the National Energy Balance Report of the Energy Research Company (EPE, 2020). One of the problems resulting from its extract ion, the generation of effluents, including produced water (PW), has been a matter of concern for environmental authorities (AL - GHOUTI et al., 2019; BENTO, 2020).

PW is the effluent generated in greater quantity during onshore and offshore oil extraction, reaching a ratio of 3:1 volume per oil production (AL -GHOUTI et al., 2019). The United States is the largest producer of water as effluent from oil extraction. In Brazil, the mark of 2.8 billion barrels of water produced from the extraction of oil and natu ral gas offshore was reached in 2020 (DA MOTTA et al., 2013; ANP, 2020). Its complex composition basically formed by organic and inorganic compounds (AL -GHOUTI et al., 2019). In environmental terms, the organic fraction is of most concern. It is believed t hat naphthenic acids (NA) are the most toxic component of this effluent, as they are highly soluble in water, their exposure is higher to aquatic organisms (CAMUS et al., 2015; AHMAD et al., 2020; BAKKE et al., 2013; CLEMENTE and FEDORAK, 2005).

NA refer t o the complex class of cycloaliphatic carboxylic acids present in crude oil in different concentrations depending on the source (CLEMENTE and FEDORAK, 2005). They are found predominantly in immature and biodegraded oils, heavy oils and PW. Because it does not undergo sufficient catagenesis or the biodegrading action of bacterium, the oil extraction well contains a greater amount of NA (GRUBER et al., 2012; YANG et al., 2019; ROSS et al., 2012; GAGN√â et al., 2016; SCOTT et al., 2007). As a tool to quantify the toxicity of effluents, ecotoxicological assays measure the effects on test organisms caused by exposure to a toxic agent (ALZAHRANI et al., 2013). The assay using the marine bacterium Vibrio fischeri is the most used, and uses its biolu- minescent property to measure the inhibition of light emission by the presence of toxic substances (RIZZO, 2011; POLEZA et al., 2008; BENTO, 2020).

Jones et al. (2011) found that the concentration required to produce a 50% reduc- tion in light emission by the bacterium Vibrio fischeri ranged from 0.004 ‚Äì 0.7 mM for 35 NA studied, noting that the higher the number of carbons in the chain, the greater was the toxicity obtained. Fang et al. (2019) obtained an inhibitory effect of 32% in ecotoxi- city assays using Vibrio fischeri exposed to PW samples collected in Canada. Allied to monitoring PW toxicity, several treatment processes have been studied and applied to the restricted conditions existing in offshore environments to make the effluent suitable for disposal following local legislation (BENALLY et al., 2019). Ad- sorption processes have been gaining prominence due to their good efficiency in remov- ing NA, simple installation and maintenance (CAMPOS et al., 2018). The use of adsor- bent materia ls with high surface area and porosity, such as activated carbon, has been extensively studied in the treatment of PW (HENDGES et al., 2021).

The objective of this work was to study the adsorption of NA in aqueous solutions to reduce acute toxicity using t he marine bacterium Vibrio fischeri as a test organism. The prepared synthetic solution simulates the concentration of NA commonly found in raw PW samples.
2. Materials and methods
2.1. NA synthetic solution and quantification methodology

Cyclohexanecarboxylic acid (CHC) and cyclohexanebutyric acid (CHB) were purchased from Sigma -Aldrich (Table 1), with purity >98%. The 100 mg/L solutions of the acids were prepared in 0.05 M NaOH solution in deionized water, with moderate agitation for 1 hour for total solubiliz ation (HENDGES et al., 2021). NA quantification was performed using a Shimadzu UV -1800 spectrophotometer at 210 nm. The maximum absorptivity of aliphatic carboxylic acids occurs in the range of 200 -220 nm, the ultraviolet region subject to interferences. S tandard solutions were prepared in the range of 20 -100 mg/L (MARTINEZ -IGLESIAS et al., 2015).

2.3. Study of the ideals pH and activated carbon concentration

Initially, a study of the effects of pH variation and activated carbon concentration was carried out. The pH of the raw solution (around 12) was adjusted with HCl 1M solu- tion to 4, 6 and 8, while the activated carbon was dosed at concentrations of 5, 10 an d 20 g/L. The adsorption assays followed the ASTM D3860 -98 methodology (ASTM, 2020). The adsorption tests in Falcon tubes containing 30 mL of the solution for 24 hours with an agitation of 150 RPM and a temperature of 25¬∫C were carried out in a shaker incubator model SL -223-PORLAB. After this period, the solution was vacuum filtered with a glass fiber membrane of 0.45 Œºm. All tests were performed in triplicate and with prior drying of activated carbon at a temperature of 105 ¬∞C for 3 hours. The NA removal efficiency was calculated according to Equation 1.

2.6. Ecotoxicological assays using Vibrio fischeri

Microtox is an acute toxicity test that uses the marine bacterium Vibrio fischeri as test organism. Its bioluminescence is used to estimate the toxicological risks of chemical substances (PARK and HEE, 2001). The concentration of the toxic agent capable of re- ducing light emission by 50% after a certain exposure time is expressed as EC 50 (AL- ZAHRANI et al., 2013). The acute toxicity tests, using Vibrio fischeri , followed the meth- odology described in NBR 15411 -3:2021 and were performed with the Microtox¬Æ sys- tem, model M500 Analyzer from Modern Water, coupled with the MicrotoxOmniTM soft- ware, SDI version 4.0 (ABNT, 2021). Toxicity tests were performed with a blank c on- taining only diluent, nine dilutions for the raw sample, and four dilutions for the treated sample (dilution factor equal to 2). Luminescence was measured before and after contact with each concentration of the sample, at times of 5, 15 and 30 minutes. Results were expressed as percent inhibition and EC 50,30 min .
3. Results and discussion
3.1. Study of ideals pH and activated carbon concentration
Figures 2 and 3 illustrate the results obtained for the adsorption tests varying pH and activated carbon concentration for CHB and CHC, respectively.
Figure 43. Final removal of CHB for different pH and activated carbon concentrations.

A tendency of increase in the removal of NA when the pH is reduced was ob- served, reaching removals above 80% at pH = 4. As for the concentration of activated carbon, no tendency was observed in the removal of NA, reaching close values in the same pH. In this sense, the conditions defined for the adsorption kinetics tests were pH = 4 and 6, and activated carbon concentration equal to 5 g/L, which presented the best re- sults.

At higher pH, the carbon surface charge is predomin antly negative, which makes interaction difficult in this range, the adsorbate molecules are in the form of carboxylate anions, which promotes electrostatic repulsion with the carbon surface (CASTILLA, 2004). The low removal obtained at higher pH suggests that the hydrophobic interaction plays a more important role in the adsorption of NA than electrostatic interactions, re- quiring a pH reduction to reduce the negative surface charge of activated carbon (NIASAR et al., 2016). At pH = 4, activated carbon has a neutral charge on its surface (Figure 1), which favored the interaction with NA molecules. At this pH, the molecules are in their neutral form, as the medium is at a pH lower than their respective pKa (SRI-

3.2. Experiments for equilibrium time and adsorption kinetics determination
Figure 4 illustrates the kinetic profile obtained for the adsorption tests of CHB and CHC in contact with activated carbon at pH = 4 and pH = 6.
Figure 45. Kinetic profile obtained from the adsorption of CHC and CHB at pH =4 and

The maximum adsorption capacity was reached in 120 minutes for CHB removal and 210 minutes for CHC removal, also called equilibrium times. This observed kinetic profile is due to the fact that at the beginning there is a large amount of empty sites avail- able in the adsorbent, which decreases with time. (CAMPOS et al., 2018). In addition, the repulsive forces of the adsorbed molecules prevent adsorption at other sites (OSTROSKI et al., 2020). It can also be observed that the CHB presented lower values of C/C 0 at the final time, which shows its greater selectivity at the carbon surface during adsorption. Niasar et al. (2016) reached equilibriu m in 480 minutes in NA adsorption using granular activated carbon. Campos et al. (2018) reached equilibrium in 360 minutes in the removal of naphthenics present in aviation kerosene using activated carbon prepared from Umba√∫ba wood. Martinez -Iglesias et al . (2016) reached an equilibrium time of 2880 minutes in the removal of a 40 mg/L solution of naphthenics at pH 4 and activated carbon dosage of 57 mg/L.
Figure 5 presents the fit of the kinetic models (pseudo -first order and pseudo -sec- ond order) obtained t o the experimental data. Table 5 summarizes the kinetic parameters for both NA.
Figure 46. Fitting the experimental data to the kinetic models (a) pseudo -first order (CHC), (b) pseudo -first order (CHB), (c) pseudo -second order (CHC) and (d) pseudo - second order (CHB)

Table 24. Kinetic parameters obtained from the adsorption of CHC and CHB with acti- vated carbon. Organic acid Qe (exp) mg/g Pseudo -first ordem Pseudo -second ordem Qe (pred) (mg/g) k1 (min- 1) R¬≤ Qe (pred) (mg/g) k2 (g/mg.min) R¬≤ CHC CHB

The pseudo -second order model presented the best fits to the experimental data in the removal of CHB and CHC, with a correlation coefficient (R¬≤) close to 1 and closer values between Q e adjusted and Q e experimental, while the pseudo -first order model order showed low fit and negative values for K 1, therefore, without physical meaning. The pseudo -second order model defines that chemissorption is the limiting step of the adsorp- tion proce ss, it involves the donation or exchange of electrons between the adsorbate and the adsorbent. Such interactions occur until the functional sites on the activated carbon surface are fully occupied. After this step, additional interactions can occur during the diffusion of the adsorbate in the porous. (HO and MACKAY, 1999) Benally et al. (2019), Islam et al. (2018) and Ostroski et al. (2020) also observed a better fit of the experimental data referring to the adsorption of NA to the pseudo -second order model , using xerogel carbon, granular activated carbon and activated carbon as ad- sorbents, respectively.

The Weber -Morris model helps to describe the adsorption mechanism present in the evaluated process. The mechanism of this model includes 3 steps: (i) mass t ransfer through the outer boundary layer of liquid that surrounds the molecule, (ii) adsorption at a location on the surface, which can be internal or external, being faster, and (iii) diffusion of molecules in the pores of the adsorbent (ISLAM et al., 201 8; SANTHI, MANON- MANI and SMITHA, 2010). The kinetic parameters are described in Table 6. In this approach, diffusion was not the limiting step, as the linear coefficients ob- tained were different from zero. In addition, the diffusion constant (K d) was decre ased along the steps, indicating a reduction in the diffusion rate until reaching equilibrium. On the other hand, the constant C, which indicates the resistance of the boundary layer in the adsorption phenomenon, increased throughout stages 1, 2 and 3 for most cases (VIDAL et al., 2014; ISLAM et al., 2018). A reduction of the values of the diffusion constants along the steps is another indication that the intraparticle diffusion mechanism is not the only limiting step of the adsorption process, then, othe r mechanisms or interactions (ad- sorption on the external surface and diffusion inside the pores) must be acting simultane- ously (BHATTACHARYYA and SHARMA, 2005; CAMPOS et al., 2018).

Campos et al. (2018) analyzed the fit of the experimental data of the adso rption of dodecanoic acid with activated carbon prepared from Umba√∫ba wood to the intraparticle diffusion model and observed the same behavior verified in this work. Islam et al. (2018) achieved a good experimental fit (R¬≤ > 0.9) to the intraparticle diffu sion model in the adsorption of NA with granular activated carbon, but 2 steps were observed, with the first step indicating the diffusion in the film and the second, diffusion in the pores.

3.3. Adsorption isotherm determination
Figure 6 presents the fits to the isotherm models to the adsorption data of CHB and CHC.
Figure 47. Fit the experimental data to the isotherm models (a) Langmuir, (b) Freun- dlich and (c) Temkin.

The Langmuir model does not represent the actual behavior of the adsorption re- sults, as it assumes a homogeneous adsorption surface, while the activated carbon surface used in this work has a heterogeneous characteristic, due to the presence of smooth and rough parts on its surface (METCALF, 2003). The Temkin model also did not present a good fit (R¬≤ < 0,9), so it is not possible to sta te that the heat of adsorption decreases linearly with the coverage of the adsorbent surface (MAJD et al., 2022). The Freundlich model, applied to heterogeneous surfaces, showed good fits (R¬≤ > 0.9) for adsorption of CHC and CHB (Table 7). The K F parameter , which measures the adsorptive capacity of activated carbon, was higher for the organic substance CHC, indicating greater adsorption efficiency. For the adsorption process to be considered favorable, the parameter 1/n must present values between 0 and 1 , but in both cases the values obtained were above 1, indi- cating that the process in question is unfavorable (BANSAL and GOYAL, 2005).
Table 26. Parameters obtained from the Freundlich model. Organic acid Parameters

Another important factor is the size of the carbon chain. Scarllet et al. (2012) men- tion that the increase in the carbon chain makes hydrophobic interactions more intense, although they are less effective than electrostatic interactions. However, this factor was not significant, as a higher K F value was obtained for CHC, which has a smaller carbon chain compared to CHB. Despite that, lower C/C 0 values obtained for the CHB in the kinetic tests may also indicate the influence of this factor.

Studying isotherm models in the adsorption of NA using granular activated car- bon, Islam et al. (2018) obtained a better fit to the Freundlich model with R¬≤ = 0.88; K F = 7.35 and 1/n = 0.7 2. Martinez -Iglesias et al. (2015) also found the best fit to the experi- mental data using the Freundlich model, obtaining values of R¬≤ = 0.97 in the adsorption of 2-naphthoic acid using granular activated carbon.
3.4. Ecotoxicological assays using Vibrio fis cheri
Figure 7 illustrates the percent inhibition results for Vibrio fischeri obtained for pre and post -treated samples of CHB and CHC.
Figure 48. Inhibition percentage for Vibrio fischeri obtained after contact with pre and post treatment solutions containing CHB and CHC.

CHB was more toxic with a higher percentage of inhibition when compared to CHC (raw solutions). In addition, the treatment process using activated carbon made it possibl e to reduce toxicity for both NA, reaching 78% and 29% removal for CHB and CHC, respectively. The results of EC 20,30 min are presented in Table 8.
Sample CE 20,30 min (%) CHC raw 26,61 CHC treated 73,94 CHB raw 0,58 CHB treated 71,25

Both organic substances were considered toxic, as they had a defined EC20 value. The adsorption treatment process was able to reduce the toxicity of the samples, since the value obtained for EC 20,30 min for the treated samples was higher than the raw samples. In terms of EC 50,30 min , CHC was considered slightly toxic (EC 50,30 min > 81,9%) and CHB ver y toxic (EC 50,30 min = 4.97%), according to the classification defined in the literature (BULICH, 1982; COLEMAN and QURESHI, 1985; CALLEJA et al., 1986). Treatment with adsorption on activated carbon made it possible to reduce the toxicity of the CHB solut ion to levels considered to be slightly toxic (EC 50,30 min > 81.9%). While for the CHC solution, all the samples presented EC 50,30 min > 81,9%, being classified as slightly toxic.

Adsorption of a synthetic solution containing 1000 mg/L of 1,4 -cyclohexanedi- carboxylic acid using activated carbon produced from the bark of Orbignya phalerata obtained 37% removal in 60 minutes (OSTROSKI et al., 2018). For the same NA, ad- sorption using co mmercial granular activated carbon reached removal of 70% during 500 minutes (NIASAR et al., 2016).

Fang et al. (2019) evaluated AN removal using UV, UV/Persulfate and UV/H 2O2 as oxidizing agents and compared the toxicity to Vibrio fischeri obtained from raw and treated PW samples. A decrease in the percentage of inhibition was observed after 15 minutes, reaching 40% inhibition for the raw sample and 11% for a dosage of 2 mM of persulfate. However, as it is a chemical treatment process, the use of advanced oxidative processes can generate undesirable by -products, often increasing toxicity, in addition to having a high cost and difficult operation (CUERDA -CORREA et al., 2020). Scott et al. (2008) studied the removal of NA in PW samples using t reatment via ozonation and an- alyzed the toxicity in Vibrio fischeri pre and post -treatment. The authors verified that the complete mineralization of NA was not necessary for the sample to become non -toxic, reaching the result in 50 minutes. Despite the hig h efficiency, the large volumes of PA generated and the high cost inherent to the oxidation process via ozone should compose an economic feasibility study to apply of this method in the effluent management model in question, according to the author.
4. Concl usion

This study investigated the adsorption of NA as CHB and CHC in aqueous solu- tion using granular activated carbon and the toxicity of pre and post -treatment solutions. The adsorption kinetics were evaluated, CHC and CHB presented equilibrium times of 210 and 120 minutes, respectively, and the pseudo -second order model best represented the experimental data of adsorption of CHC and CHB. The Freundlich isotherm model properly described the adsorption of CHB and CHC. The acute ecotoxicity assays showed inhibition percentages of 91.9% and 32.0% for the raw solutions of CHB and CHC, re- spectively. Both organic substances were considered toxic by the EC 20,30 min values obtained. In terms of EC 50,30 min , CHB was very toxic (EC 50,30 min = 4.97%), while CHC was c onsidered slightly toxic (EC 50,30 min > 81,9%). Treatment via adsorption using acti- vated carbon reduced the toxicity of the CHB solution to slightly toxic levels (EC 50,30 min > 81.9%), while for CHC, all the samples presented EC 50,30 min > 81,9%, being cla ssified as slightly toxic.
